reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: Direct Investment with Gobi Finance Non-Bank Finance Institution. Gobi Finance Non-Bank Finance Institution

description.narrative: Support the establishment of a sound private, well-functioning, equitable financial sector that fulfills critical roles in a market economy, most importantly financial intermediation – the efficient generation and allocation of savings to their most productive use.

This award strives to support the establishment of a sound private, well-functioning, equitable financial sector that fulfills critical roles in a market economy. More specifically, this includes Direct loans to foreign private-sector enterprises from target countries, typically issued through a U.S. sponsor or borrower. The loan tenor is typically between 5 and 25 years, with a maximum of 30 years, depending on the type of project and its debt servicing capability. Interest and fees will vary depending on the project.. Support for new consumer loans in Mongolia.

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

mailing-address.narrative: 1100 New York Avenue, NW Washington, D.C. 20527???????

description.narrative: The primary goal of U.S. assistance to Mongolia is to strengthen the country's institutional capacity to meet its global, regional, and domestic commitments. After several years of double-digit economic growth, Mongolia's natural resource-based economy faltered in 2014 as government missteps aggravated the effect of falling commodity prices on global markets. Foreign direct investment into Mongolia came to a virtual halt in 2015 and economic growth declined precipitously. These trends magnify the importance of U.S. assistance, now limited to Mongolia's defense, law enforcement, and border forces. U.S. training and equipment will help continue the professionalization of Mongolia's defense forces, bolster Mongolia's participation in United Nations Peacekeeping Operations (UNPKO), and promote continued participation in missions in Afghanistan. U.S. assistance will also continue to support priority nonproliferation activities due to Mongolia's highly porous borders and geographic proximity to regional proliferators.
